Virginia Woolf in her 1927 essay "The New Biography": "it would seem to us that the life which is in- creasingly real to us is the fictitious life; it dwells in the personality rather than the act" (234)
"Theories of Autobiography," chapter two of Suzanne Nalbantian's Aesthetic Autobi- ography: From Life to Art in Marcel Proust, James Joyce, Virginia Woolf and Anais Nin, 26-42

Language 107
Similarly, Emile Benveniste argues, "It is in and through language that man constitutes himself as a sub- ject, because language alone establishes the concept of 'ego' in reality" (224)

Kristeva makes the point that "all enunciation, whether of a word or a sentence, is thetic ... [requiring that] the subject must separate from and through his image, from and through his objects" (98).
Andrew Sarris's "Notes on the Auteur Theory in 1962"

Lucien Dällenbach as well. Peter Wollen also uses the term in his discussion of the auteur theory: "Sometimes ... separate texts-those of the cameraman or the actors-may force themselves into prominence so that the film becomes an indecipherable palimpsest" (105)
